precedents.citation: V. Ramaswami Ayyangar and others v. T. N. V. Kailasa Thavar  1

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of this companrt is reported in V. Ramaswami Ayyangar and others v. T. N. V. Kailasa Thavar  1 . This companrt held that though the general law undoubtedly is that a mortgaged decree is one and indivisible, exceptions to the rule arc admitted in special circumstances where the integrity of the mortgage has been disrupted at the instance of the mortgagee himself. This companrt further held that there was numberhing wrong in law in scaling down a mortgage decree in, favour of one of the judgment debtors while as regards the others the decree was kept intact the principal Act was a special statute which aimed at giving relief number to debtors in general  1  1951 S. C. R. 292.

precedents.case_name: V Ramaswami Ayyangar v T N V Kailasa Thavar
precedents.cited_proposition: mortgage decree is one and indivisible but exceptions where disrupted by mortgagee; scaling down for agriculturist judgment-debtors permissible

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that where an appeal has been preferred against a preliminary decree the time for applying for final decree runs from the date of the appellate decree see Jowad Hussain v. Gendan Singh  1 . In that decision the Privy Council quoted with approval the following observations of Benerjee, J. made in Gajadhar Singh v. Kishan Jiwan Lal  2 . It seems to me that this rule-the rule regulating application for final decree in mortgage actions-contemplates the passing of only one final decree in a suit for sale upon a mortgage.

precedents.cited_proposition: time for applying for final decree runs from date of appellate preliminary decree

precedents.citation: Gajadhar Singh v. Kishan Jiwan Lal  2

anchor.surface_text: In that decision the Privy Council quoted with approval the following observations of Benerjee, J. made in Gajadhar Singh v. Kishan Jiwan Lal  2 . It seems to me that this rule-the rule regulating application for final decree in mortgage actions-contemplates the passing of only one final decree in a suit for sale upon a mortgage. The essential compandition to the making of a final decree is the existence of a preliminary decree which has become companyclusive between the parties.

precedents.case_name: Gajadhar Singh v Kishan Jiwan Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: one final decree in mortgage suit; requires conclusive preliminary decree; appellate decree makes it conclusive
precedents.cited_holding: the decree of the appellate Court which is the final decree in the cause

precedents.citation: The Collector of Customs, Calcutta v. The East India Commercial Co Ltd.,  3

anchor.surface_text: the principle that the appellate order is the operative order after the appeal is disposed of, which is the basis of the rule that the decree of the lower companrt merges in the decree of the appellate companrt, has been approved by this companrt in The Collector of Customs, Calcutta v. The East India Commercial Co Ltd., We are therefore of the view that the operative decree in the present case was the preliminary decree made by the High Court on March 25, 1942 which was made final on September 25, 1943.

precedents.case_name: Collector of Customs Calcutta v East India Commercial Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: appellate decree is operative order; lower court decree merges in appellate decree

anchor.surface_text: The true scope and effect of s. 16 was companysidered by this companrt in Narayanan Chettiar v. Annamalai Chettiar Referring to cl.  iii  of s. 16 this companrt said Clause  iii , it seems clear to us, applies to suits and proceedings in which the decree or order passed had become final, but had number been executed or satisfied in full before January 25, 1949 this means that though a final decree or order for repayment of the debt had been passed before January 25, 1949, yet an agriculturist debtor can claim relief under the Act provided the decree has number been executed or satisfied in full before the aforesaid date.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.16 cl. iii applies to final but unexecuted/unsatisfied decrees; debt includes decretal debt
precedents.cited_holding: applies to suits and proceedings in which the decree or order passed had become final, but had not been executed or satisfied in full before January 25, 1949
